sections.snippet:
To create a commit to reverse another, simply:

```shell
git revert [sha-ref]
```

Use `-n` for a dry run.

This will work for reverting commits that are not merges.
sections.title: Reverting regular commits

sections.snippet:
To revert a merge use the `-m` option.

The `-m` option require the parent number. The parent number is which parent you would like the original state to look like.

You can figure out the number of the parents by the order of listed parents in `git log`:

```shell
commit efc295a0240ee745d2f9cbe8c52d810ac8b780f2
Merge: 957f237 1e74f7e
Author: Greg Larrenaga <greg.larrenaga@thinksolid.com>
Date:   Fri Aug 15 16:01:29 2014 -0700

    Merge branch 'deploys' into HEAD
```
   
For example above, `957f237` is 1, and `1e74f7e` is 2.
sections.title: Reverting merges
